title: 115_hr4577
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Explosives Detection Canine Capacity Building Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines terms related to the evaluation of explosives detection working canines, including behavioral, medical, and technical standards. The Act sets standards for evaluating explosives detection working canines, covering factors like search techniques, communication, testing conditions, and odor libraries. SEC. 3. DOMESTIC CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a working group to develop a decentralized domestic canine breeding network for explosives detection canines within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The group will include representatives from the Transportation Security Administration, Science and Technology Directorate, domestic canine associations, universities, and breeders. The working group established by the Secretary of Homeland Security will have two Chairpersons approved by the Administrator for the Transportation Security Administration. Within 180 days, the group will submit preliminary standards for the domestic canine breeding network and training. The Transportation Security Administration will submit a strategy for expanding the domestic canine breeding network within 180 days, based on recommendations from a working group. The Administrator will consult with the Department of Homeland Security in developing this strategy. The Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Customs and Border Protection, United States Secret Service, and other relevant components will work together to expand the domestic explosives detection canine breeding network to meet operational needs. A working group will terminate two years after submitting the required strategy for this expansion. SEC. 4. ACQUIRING BASELINE CAPACITY.

Within 270 days of recommendations submission, the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration must establish baseline behavioral, medical, and technical standards for explosives detection canines. These standards will be integrated into all TSA canine contracts to enhance detection capabilities against terrorist threats. The Administrator reserves the right to revise these standards as needed.

SEC. 5. NONAPPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ACT. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the working group established under this Act.
